The FBI had a rough start. It finally cleaned up its act, and the trust in its investigations grew after the Vietnam War. In a single presidential administration, the top leaders all changed. That led to a federal law enforcement agency ripe for political weaponization.

POTUS summoned his party's nominee to the White House, warning them of "credible information of Russian influence" in the process. Meanwhile, nobody notified the other candidate so they could take protective measures.

At the same time, the DOJ elected to soft pedal Hillary's mail servers containing classified information. [Do not forget that Hillary had to return a bunch of White House property that was not hers when Bill's term ended.]

The comments about reopening the Hillary investigation by the FBI Director were unprecedented. [No other director ever gave such a press briefing.] Days later, the FBI Director held another presser saying Hillary did not mean to do it.

One could argue the first presser intended to help Trump, but the second only benefited Hillary. Obama should have fired Comey after the first statement. After the second one, it is ridiculous that Trump had to do it.

Months later, when the FBI's text scandals came to light, it cast a shadow over anything the FBI said. Their actions since then have remained less than candid or transparent.

The distrust is in the upper hierarchy, not the thousands of agents who do most of the work.
